title: INFLUENCE OF DRUG-POLYMER INTERACTIONS ON RELEASE KINETICS OF PLGA AND PLA/PEG NPS

authors.name: Merve Gul
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia
Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)

authors.name: Ida Genta
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia

authors.name: Maria M. Perez Madrigal
affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)

authors.name: Carlos Aleman
affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)
Barcelona Research Center for Multiscale Science and Engineering, EEBE, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya

authors.name: Enrica Chiesa
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia

summary: This research investigates drug-polymer interactions to develop novel drug delivery strategies against antimicrobial resistance using microfluidic-based synthesis of nano-sized carriers. The study found that CURC-loaded PLGA NPs demonstrated better controlled drug delivery due to hydrophobic interactions and showed no cytotoxic effects with progressive cellular internalization.
methods: Microfluidic-based synthesis using Y-shape microfluidic chip for nano-sized drug delivery carriers. NPs coating to skin patches. Characterization included TEM imaging, size distribution analysis (PDI ≤0.2), zeta potential measurements, and encapsulation efficiency determination.
results: PLGA NPs: Dₕ = 61.91 ± 1.86 nm, ζ = 13.74 ± 0.97 mV, EE% = 2.81 ± 0.81%, payload = 2.51 ± 0.57 µg/mg. CURC-loaded PLGA NPs showed slower release rate and better controlled delivery due to hydrophobic interactions. No or slight cytotoxic effect observed on NHDFs with progressive cellular internalization of NPs.
